articles.headline: Charitable Giving by Corporations Is Also About Getting, a New Study Finds
articles.snippet: An analysis of corporate philanthropy finds that donations to causes affiliated with politicians look a lot like lobbying.
articles.abstract: An analysis of corporate philanthropy finds that donations to causes affiliated with politicians look a lot like lobbying.
articles.lead_paragraph: Corporate philanthropy, business leaders would have us believe, is the ringing voice of a company’s social conscience. Exxon Mobil may stand accused of misleading investors and shareholders about what it knew about climate change, but the ExxonMobil Foundation’s multimillion-dollar contributions to end deaths from malaria and to train women in developing countries should, executives hope, balance the ethical ledger.

articles.headline: White House Turf Battle Threatens to Delay Tax Law Rollout
articles.snippet: The Office of Management and Budget and the Treasury Department are at odds over the Treasury’s longtime independence in writing tax regulations.
articles.abstract: The Office of Management and Budget and the Treasury Department are at odds over the Treasury’s longtime independence in writing tax regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A power struggle between two of President Trump’s top cabinet members threatens to delay implementation of the new tax law and could give lobbyists and political hands in the White House greater ability to shape critical decisions about which types of businesses benefit from the law.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Where Today’s Black Church Leaders Stand on Activism
articles.snippet: Fifty years after Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s assassination, black pastors are issuing a call to action and using different methods to achieve common goals.
articles.abstract: Fifty years after Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s assassination, black pastors are issuing a call to action and using different methods to achieve common goals.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Our God!” the worshipers belted out, swaying inside a towering cathedral. “Our God!”

articles.headline: Amazon Has Lots of Company as Trump Slams ‘Stupid’ Businesses
articles.snippet: Tech firms, military contractors, carmakers, cellphone companies, financial firms, sports leagues and Wall Street giants are all in his Twitter cross hairs.
articles.abstract: Tech firms, military contractors, carmakers, cellphone companies, financial firms, sports leagues and Wall Street giants are all in his Twitter cross hairs.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: White House Tries to Tamp Down Trade War Fears as China Retaliates
articles.snippet: As markets seesawed and industries fretted, American officials held out the possibility that tariffs outlined this week might never go into effect.
articles.abstract: As markets seesawed and industries fretted, American officials held out the possibility that tariffs outlined this week might never go into effect.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — White House officials moved quickly on Wednesday to calm fears of a potential trade war with China, saying the administration’s proposed tariffs were a “threat” that would ultimately help, not hurt, the United States economy, hours after China said it would punish American products with similar levies.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Facebook Says Cambridge Analytica Harvested Data of Up to 87 Million Users
articles.snippet: Mr. Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, will appear before multiple congressional committees next week. It is part of the company’s efforts to be more open about its work.
articles.abstract: Mr. Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, will appear before multiple congressional committees next week. It is part of the company’s efforts to be more open about its work.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facebook on Wednesday said that the data of up to 87 million users may have been improperly shared with a political consulting firm connected to President Trump during the 2016 election — a figure far higher than the estimate of 50 million that had been widely cited since the leak was reported last month.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: ‘The Business of War’: Google Employees Protest Work for the Pentagon
articles.snippet: Thousands of employees have signed a letter calling on their C.E.O. to pull out of a project that could be used to improve drone strike targeting.
articles.abstract: Thousands of employees have signed a letter calling on their C.E.O. to pull out of a project that could be used to improve drone strike targeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Thousands of Google employees, including dozens of senior engineers, have signed a letter protesting the company’s involvement in a Pentagon program that uses artificial intelligence to interpret video imagery and could be used to improve the targeting of drone strikes.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Daisuke Wakabayashi
